column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	250	We know that 17 new schools are to open next year
column2: only two of which have a permanent home that we know about. We also know that there are about 350 schools in the schools building programme. This comes to approximately 1
column3: 000 when schools that are trying to get into that programme are added in. Does the Minister have enough money? I have raised this issue repeatedly. I am glad to see next year's increase. I am not talking about the capital plan; I am talking about next year's budget. If the summer works programme and the minor works grant are to be paid next year
column4: they will take out a lot of the budget because they were not paid out or dealt with this year. In talking about the capital plan
column5: when people hear the Minister talking about the number of PE halls to be built
column6: the number of prefabs to be replaced
column7: the number of general purpose rooms and the number of schools
column8: they want to know what the delivery on the ground will be. Do we need to put up with schools that are falling apart and schools with very high energy bills because of bad structures or will we see actual delivery on the ground?

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	251	There will be a summer works programme next year. From speaking to principals and school boards of management
column2: I know they need a good run-in time. That announcement will need to happen sooner rather than later. There will also be a minor works programme
column3: for which there will be a good enough lead-in time. I know there is no application process involved there. The Deputy is correct in what he says about existing schools. In particular many secondary schools were built back in the late 1970s and 1980s and we need to consider retrofitting them. I have already raised that issue with my officials and I hope to progress it. Even though we have 42 new schools
column4: many of them were chosen on the basis of demographics. We cannot allow existing school accommodation not to get infrastructure enhancement. The Deputy's suggestion of looking at the economics of a school building in terms of heating and retrofitting is important.

column1: #ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	252	I will pick up on one point
column2: the minor works grant. This is normally paid out in November every year
column3: although it was not paid in one year
column5: at the bottom of the recession. This year
column6: according to the figures the Minister has produced
column7: it is not likely to be paid and there is a concern the schools will not get it in November
column8: as they have in the past
column9: and that it will be pushed forward to January. While that might only seem a short period to wait
column10: the truth is the Government will not have paid it in 2018 at a time when the economy is rising
column11: and that will make it one of two exceptional years when it has not been paid. It is also the case that schools have come to depend on the minor works grant for cash flow and for planning the school year. They get particular grants of money at different times of the school year and this is one that comes in at a good time
column12: that is
column13: at the end of the calendar year. Is there any way it can be paid out in November? We in Fianna Fáil want to make it a statutory obligation of the Department of Education and Skills to pay it out in November. Will the Minister confirm it will be paid in November or will schools have to wait until January?

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	253	It is an issue I have already raised with my officials. The timing is very important. School principals are under enough pressure without delayed funding. I have asked my officials to ensure that money for minor works grants is paid at the end of this year
column2: not in January. If we can do it in November
column3: that will be great
column4: but I cannot commit to that here today. One thing I can commit to is that I want this paid out before Christmas.

column1: #RobertTroy	unknown-#RobertTroy-party	unknown-#RobertTroy-dob	unknown-#RobertTroy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	254	The question relates to a school building project that is under way
column2: namely
column3: the relocation of Curraghmore national school to the Ardmore Road in Mullingar
column4: which was due to be completed in September but is far from completed. I would like an update on the project and an outline of what role the Department can play in ensuring this contractor lives up to the timeframe stipulated in the contract that was awarded.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	255	I have been made aware of the building project for the school to which the Deputy is referring. Delays have
column2: unfortunately
column3: been experienced in delivering this project. These arose because the contractor encountered unforeseen bad ground conditions
column4: together with severe weather events
column5: which we will all remember from earlier this year. The project had been scheduled for completion for September 2018 but
column6: in view of the issues met by the contractor
column7: the likely completion date is now April 2019. I know how disappointing this is for the school and I understand how difficult it is for it to manage a growing enrolment until its new building is in place. It is
column8: however
column9: in the nature of any building project
column10: whether it is a school
column11: an office block or a house
column12: that unforeseen issues can arise. The objective is always to deal with these as efficiently as possible to minimise delay. The project is being delivered by the local county council
column13: which is continuing to pursue the contractor for as speedy a delivery of the project as possible. The council has the full support of my Department in its efforts to achieve this without compromising the integrity of the building being delivered. To ensure the school is kept fully up to date with progress on the project
column14: the county council will be providing the board of management with monthly updates. The intention is that this approach will provide accurate and precise information to help the school to plan and manage its needs until its permanent accommodation is available.

column1: #RobertTroy	unknown-#RobertTroy-party	unknown-#RobertTroy-dob	unknown-#RobertTroy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	256	The Minister is right in some respects. This school was promised a new building in 2013 and it has been waiting a hell of a long time. It is currently working out of very substandard accommodation. Despite that
column2: it is fortunate to have excellent teachers and the quality of education has not been diminished. However
column3: it is not right and not fair for the students and the teachers to have to put up with the facilities they are operating from. There was an absolute logjam in September because
column4: at the Department's request
column5: the school took in an additional junior infants class and the traffic was serious. I compliment the school authorities for staggering the opening hours to facilitate better access. While I accept there has been bad weather and unforeseen circumstances
column6: and the council has allowed the contractor a one-month extension
column7: we are now talking about a completion date of April of next year
column8: which is much longer than a month. Unforeseen circumstances are understandable but having a skeleton staff working on the development is not unforeseen circumstances. We need to bring pressure on this contractor to accelerate the effort to get these pupils into their new school without further delay.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	257	While the Deputy will be aware of the status of the project
column2: for the purposes of the public record
column3: I point out the contractor is on programme to complete the development in line with its construction programme by April 2019. More than 90% of the blockwork is complete overall
column4: with 100% of the structural blockwork complete to roof level. Concrete roof beams are almost complete and the roof steel is due on site next week. Over 45% of the mechanical installation is complete on the ground floor and over 85% of site drainage works are complete. Works have commenced on the provision of the staff car park and the set-down area
column5: including internal roads and the foundations for the boundary wall. In preparation for the opening of the new school
column6: phase one works to upgrade the footpaths on the road extraneous to the site are completed and the county council reports this has made a great improvement to the safety of this road for motorists and pedestrians. Nonetheless
column7: I take the Deputy's point in terms of the frustrations. People want to see progress
column8: particularly parents and students.

column1: #RobertTroy	unknown-#RobertTroy-party	unknown-#RobertTroy-dob	unknown-#RobertTroy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	258	The Minister is right. I drive by the school a couple of times a week and I can see that progress has been made in recent weeks
column2: so full compliments to Westmeath County Council for sitting on this contractor. However
column3: it is no secret that for weeks and months a skeleton staff was operating there. It was not the weather because there were no staff there on good days
column4: or very few staff. I want to know what penalties will be imposed. It is simply not good enough that somebody who was awarded a lucrative State contract to provide a much-needed
column5: long overdue service can delay like this
column6: for whatever reason. Maybe he is trying to keep two jobs going - I do not know - but he signed up to a contract and he is not honouring that commitment. He got a small extension
column7: not an extension until April of next year. We need to send out a clear message that if we want to provide infrastructure and services for the community at taxpayers' expense
column8: there have to be consequences for the contractors who fail to deliver that. I want the Minister to make a commitment today that those like this contractor will face consequences for not fulfilling their contractual obligations.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	259	A number of issues have arisen on the project
column2: as the Deputy will be aware from hearing it anecdotally on the ground
column3: and these have been referred to conciliation in accordance with the contract. Conciliation is confidential as it deals with contractual issues. While I cannot give the specifics of the issue in this conciliation case
column4: I take on board that the Deputy has raised this issue with a view to getting this project across the line as quickly as possible.

column1: #KathleenFunchion	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-party	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-dob	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	260	The question concerns the costs of further education. It seeks that the Minister would outline the measures taken in 2018 to reduce high costs for students accessing further education or towards tackling the rental and living costs they are faced with.

#JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	261	In 2018 my Department will spend some €450 million on access measures for further and higher education students. This includes approximately €380 million on student grants and related activities
column2: which is expected to benefit approximately 78
column3: 000 further and higher education students. Some 16
column4: 000 students are expected to be assisted in 2018 through the student assistance fund at a cost of €9 million. In addition
column6: 000 students are expected to be assisted through the fund for students with disabilities at a cost of €10 million. Under the National Access Plan for Equity of Access to Higher Education 2015-2019
column7: my predecessor as Minister
column8: Deputy Richard Bruton
column9: created a new funding stream called the programme for access to higher education
column10: PATH. To date
column11: the Minister
column12: Deputy Bruton
column13: and the Minister of State
column14: Deputy Mary Mitchell O'Connor
column15: who has responsibility in this area
column16: have secured over €16 million for the roll-out of three strands of the PATH programme aimed at increasing participation from under-represented groups in initial teacher education
column17: a new 1916 bursary fund supporting 600 students over three years
column18: and new initiatives to attract an additional 2
column19: 000 students from under-represented groups into higher education. A further 850 students will benefit from the provision of scholarships and bursaries to students from disadvantaged backgrounds. The block grant paid to higher education institutions includes a specific weighting to promote access to higher education. This involves an additional premium for all eligible access students and takes account of the additional costs of recruiting and retaining students from under-represented backgrounds. For those from targeted socio-economic groups and mature students
column20: this is applied for the first two years of course duration. For people with disabilities
column21: a further weighting is applied for the entire length of the course.Regarding other steps
column22: the national student accommodation strategy was published in July 2017 to promote and enhance the supply of student accommodation in line with the timescale envisaged in Rebuilding Ireland. It sets a target of 7
column23: 000 additional purpose-built student accommodation bed spaces to be delivered by the end of 2019 and the construction of at least 21
column24: 000 propose-built student accommodation bed spaces by 2024. This initial target will be exceeded with over 10
column25: 000 bed spaces completed or on site as of October 2018. Price is ultimately a function of supply and demand and the national student accommodation strategy is explicitly aimed at increasing the supply of accommodation available to students.

column1: #KathleenFunchion	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-party	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-dob	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	262	I raise the issue because the cost of going to third level has moved beyond the reach of many people. In the first instance
column2: fees are at the €3
column3: 000 mark while many people fail to qualify for the SUSI grant. While I appreciate that there is a Minister of State with responsibility for higher education who is not the Minister
column4: we need to look at the SUSI system and how grants are given out. A great deal of reform of SUSI is required because it can be difficult just to access and deal with the body. The rules around how far one has to be from a college are very rigid which impacts students from rural areas more than those who can travel to college from home on a daily basis. That brings me to the matter of rental costs for students. Many students are now forced to commute or may end up giving college because they cannot afford the cost of living along with rent and fees. We have a good record of higher education that we are at risk of damaging due to increasing fees and costs of living. While a promise is there for 7
column5: 000 units
column6: we need to see a lot more being done a lot faster to provide student accommodation. Otherwise we will slip behind in our record on third level education.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	263	I take the point on the wider constraints facing students and
column2: in most instances
column3: parents given those costs. Since the launch of the strategy
column5: 729 bed spaces have been completed or are in the planning process. The figure is broken down as follows: 5
column6: 500 bed spaces have been completed; 4
column7: 800 bed spaces are under construction; planning has been approved for nearly 8
column8: 000 bed spaces and a further 472 bed spaces are in the planning process awaiting a final decision. Student accommodation and the affordability of rent are issues we need to tackle together on a cross-Government basis. I have not yet sat down with my colleague
column9: the Minister for Housing
column10: Planning and Local Government
column11: Deputy Eoghan Murphy
column12: to discuss that but I will certainly do so very shortly.

column1: #KathleenFunchion	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-party	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-dob	unknown-#KathleenFunchion-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	264	I welcome what the Minister says about parents. At a time when a parent is letting a child fly the nest
column2: it is very worrying to be unsure about what accommodation is available
column3: whether it is up to standard and where exactly it is located. That is what is so good about purpose-built and on-campus accommodation. It gives students
column4: in particular first years
column5: and their parents the reassurance they need that they are somewhere safe and known. I appreciate that the Minister is new in the role but this is something we need to continue to work on
column6: including in the education committee. There are many studies on this. Credit unions have produced a study showing how many people are nearly being forced to use money lenders. They have got to the stage where they have borrowed to put one child through college and a second child comes along before the first has graduated. People are getting to the stage of nearly having to go to money lenders because they want their children to move on to further education. That is unacceptable in this day and age and it is a matter we must address. That is why I refer to the need to reform SUSI. Not everything is black and white and not everyone fits into the same category. The system we used to have meant one could call to a local VEC office regarding a grant but that is all gone now. It is now just a person on the phone and one either fits the category or one does not. There is no room for any sort of discretion
column7: which is not necessarily a good thing. Perhaps we can look at reform of SUSI in further discussions.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	265	I am happy to work with the committee on that. I will also be working closely with my colleague
column2: Deputy Mary Mitchell O'Connor
column3: in this regard. I am happy to take on board Deputy Funchion's suggestion that we work collectively on this matter.

column1: #MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	266	The first of my questions is on progress on secondary school extensions. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister
column2: Deputy McHugh
column3: who I consider a good friend
column4: on his elevation to a full Cabinet position. It is a position he is well capable of handling from his experience in the House. It is a great honour for him and his family and a testament to the work he has done as a Deputy representing Donegal. I look forward to working with the Minister and making him very aware of all the challenges we face in south Kildare in the education area.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	267	I thank the Deputy whose kind words I appreciate. I look forward to working with him on a number of important education matters. No doubt
column2: the Ceann Comhairle will be very interested in a number of these issues also.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	268	The Minister had better believe it.

#JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	269	I propose to take Questions Nos. 56 and 57 together. The Department is currently advancing building projects in a number of post-primary schools in the south Kildare school planning area and these projects will
column2: when completed
column3: provide additional capacity in the region of 1
column4: 700 school places. The current status of each of these projects is as follows. At St. Conleth's community college
column5: Newbridge
column6: the project is on site and is due to be completed shortly. At Athy community college
column7: the project brief has been completed and the project has been devolved to Kildare and Wicklow ETB for delivery. At Cross and Passion secondary school
column8: Kilcullen
column9: the project is at project brief stage. At Patrician College
column10: Newbridge
column11: the project is at project brief stage and at St. Paul's secondary school
column12: Monasterevin
column13: the project is at stage 2b
column14: detailed design stage. Recently
column15: my predecessor
column16: Deputy Richard Bruton
column17: announced plans for the establishment of 42 new schools over the next four years
column18: 2019 to 2022. In addition to the new schools announced
column19: there will be a need for further school accommodation in other areas in the future. While the announcement did not include a new post-primary school in the south Kildare school planning areas
column20: a review of provision at post-primary school level across the school planning areas in south Kildare is now well advanced and the outcome will be made available by the end of October. The review will include an assessment of the extent to which projected needs in the area will be met from the additional capacity being provided by the projects already approved and how any specific additional needs will be best catered for
column21: recognising the importance of maintaining a balance between existing and any additional school provision.

column1: #MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	270	I thank the Minister for his response. Given that the questions are grouped
column2: I have a fair number of points to make. I will stick to the matter of school extensions in this first supplementary contribution. As the Ceann Comhairle knows well
column3: the project at St. Paul's school in Monasterevin has been beset by numerous delays
column4: not all of which were caused by the Department of Education and Skills. While the project is at pre-qualification of contractors stage
column5: we must ensure there is no delay in moving to tender. I reassured parents this week that the change of Minister would not have any impact on that and that the Department will stand ready. I will stay in touch with the Minister on that one as
column6: I am sure
column7: will the Ceann Comhairle. Athy community college has been devolved and a service-level agreement has been established with Kildare and Wicklow ETB. There are now 440 pupils in that school but it was built for 400 and needs to be extended to accommodate 1
column8: 000 pupils. There are prefabricated buildings on site and more are coming while the school is under significant pressure. We cannot have a delay there. I am delighted to see the project for Patrician College in Newbridge go to the NDFA. The next step is planning and design and we must keep pushing because there is significant pressure on school places in the Newbridge-Kildare area. There has been a delay in the opening of the extension to St. Conleth's and that has had a particular impact on six pupils with mild to moderate intellectual and special educational needs. This is causing serious distress. Officials in the Department made the point previously that they would stand with the parents if there were any delays.The Ceann Comhairle and other public representatives in the area have worked on this matter as well. What the parents have been offered to date
column9: namely
column10: home tuition
column11: whereby they must find tutors
column12: is not sufficient. Huge distress has been caused to those parents who thought they would have places in September. In fairness to the principal of the school
column13: it is not her fault. She is doing her best to manage a very difficult situation. I ask that the special education section of the Department give every support to these parents and that we try to get these six pupils into their special accommodation as soon as possible.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	271	There are a number of schools in the area. I will say one thing about the ongoing building programme and capital plan. In my very short time in the job
column2: I have learned that I cannot walk from one end of a corridor to the other without meeting a Deputy or Senator who is looking for information on a project in the capital plan. In fairness
column3: the previous Minister
column4: Deputy Bruton
column5: introduced a communication system whereby the website shows the different stages at which the projects stand. It is important that we can communicate any changes in this regard. As for the specific schools to which the Deputy refers
column6: if any further information is needed or if the Deputy's colleagues in the Kildare South constituency need to sit down with one of the officials in the building unit
column7: I would be happy to organise that.

column1: #MartinHeydon	unknown-#MartinHeydon-party	unknown-#MartinHeydon-dob	unknown-#MartinHeydon-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	272	I thank the Minister. This is our opening shot in a process whereby I will make him familiar with the schools in south Kildare. We will continue to brief him on the impact of pressures relating to places as they develop. I welcome his original response regarding a review of the overall demographics of Kildare and pressure on places. I welcome the fact that we are very close to a final announcement on the need for increased provision beyond these extensions. The South Kildare Educate Together campaign was established in 2014. Since then
column2: we have had meetings with two taoisigh
column3: two Ministers for Education and Skills and departmental officials. Deputy McHugh is the third Minister in the job and we still have not gone away. There is huge demand from parents in Kildare South who have children at primary level for improved provision of choice at second level as well. The Department should not be surprised by this demand. Two Educate Together primary schools were opened a number of years ago in south Kildare. The Educate Together primary school in Kildare town this year has a sixth class for the first time. The parents involved travelled to Portlaoise to look at a second-level Educate Together school because they do not have that option in Kildare south
column4: and this need to be addressed. The provision of a new school would require all the decisions on the patronage process to be made and site selection and acquisition would take a long time. The review in the Department will show that we do not have much time. Two years ago I stated that one very good fit to work with the Educate Together campaign and to address these issues of pressure on spaces would be to look at the Curragh post-primary school
column5: which absolutely deserves a new building. There are great staff and students working in very difficult circumstances. A partnership or joint patronage process with Educate Together and a new school building for the Curragh could deliver increased capacity in an area between two very big towns
column6: Kildare and Newbridge
column7: that are at bursting point. It could attract pupils from primary schools such as those in Athgarvan
column8: Ballysax and Suncroft and many more in the area that all feed into those towns at present. This would rejuvenate the area. It would be a very overdue shot in the arm for the staff and students of that school. Irrespective of the location of the site and whether the Department of Defence works with us on the provision of a new site on the camp or whether we have a new site outside of the Curragh but in the surrounding area
column9: this is probably the most common-sense approach that would give us that increased capacity as quickly as possible. I have no doubt that the most recent figures the Minister's officials possess - these were compiled at the end of September - show that the pressure the Ceann Comhairle and I and other public representatives have indicated exists in the constituency of Kildare South is very real and will not be offset solely by the extensions that are proposed.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	273	The Deputy's observation on the review of the provision of post-primary schools in the general school planning areas of south Kildare is important. It is well advanced and I will certainly make it available by the end of October. Demographics is the research tool used to prioritise accommodation need. If we go back to 2011
column2: when Ruairí Quinn was in office and developing his plan for the period 2016 to 2021
column3: the measurement was to ask where the population pressures lay. My predecessor
column4: Deputy Bruton
column5: oversaw the capital programme starting in 2016. We are still in that 2016-2021 period but we do have a trajectory now over ten years and an €8.4 billion capital fund
column6: which is double the size of that for the ten years prior to the national development plan timeframe we are envisaging. I will keep the Deputy updated and ensure that the commitment given today
column7: that the review will be made available at the end of October
column8: will be honoured.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	274	On 19 February
column2: the Department of Education and Skills issued a circular to State second-level schools stating that they must offer alternative subject choices to students who do not want to study religion. This instruction applied to State-run non-religious schools run by local education and training boards and community schools. It was a very good instruction and was welcomed by those who want to see a separation of church and State and choice for people who do not hold certain religious views in terms of the education system and those who want to end discrimination and stigma. Incredibly
column3: at the beginning of this month
column4: the Department issued a new circular essentially capitulating on all this. In the intervening period
column5: there was clearly a lot of lobbying by the Catholic Church and its representatives
column6: and now the alternative choice subject is not to be offered to people who choose to opt out of religion. Can the Minister explain this?

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	275	I know that we are tight on time and that Deputy Catherine Martin wants to get in but I wish to take this opportunity
column2: as a former member of the Business Committee
column3: to thank Deputy Boyd Barrett for his collegiality and co-operation at that committee and the Ceann Comhairle and his team for a wonderful experience in how consensus politics can work in getting things done. I just wanted to put that on the public record. In February 2018
column4: my Department published Circular 0013/2018
column5: which set out an approach to the arrangements that were to be made for religious instruction and worship in education and training board and post-primary community schools. This arose as a result of concerns that multidenominational education and training board
column6: ETB
column7: schools were requiring attendance at classes with Catholic religious instruction. Section 4 of the circular provided that the school is required to ascertain parental wishes in respect of the child's attendance at such religious instruction. Where a parent did not want his or her child to receive religious instruction
column8: the school was required to provide an alternative subject. Where there was any practice of combining or including religious instruction and formation or worship in the same class time as the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment
column9: NCCA
column10: religious education syllabus
column11: parents were made aware of this fact in order that they could make an informed decision to withdraw their children from that class if this was their wish. The newly published circular to which the Deputy referred clarifies in section 3 that withdrawal with an offer of an alternative subject does not arise in respect of the NCCA religious syllabus where there is no religious instruction or faith formation. Religious education is an examinable subject just like history or geography
column12: for example. It aims to develop students' ability to examine questions of meaning
column13: purpose and relationships
column14: to help students understand
column15: respect and appreciate people's expression of their beliefs and to facilitate dialogue and reflection on the diversity of beliefs and values that inform responsible decision-making and ways of living. Crucially
column16: it is not delivered from any one religious perspective. The second important clarification is that where a school intends to provide religious instruction classes
column17: parents must give consent before admission to the class. This means that the issue of opting out does not arise because the parent has requested a place in the religious instruction class. This circular has no impact on the right of parents under the Education Act or the Constitution to opt out of any subject for reason of conscience.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	276	We need clarification here. I am aware
column2: on foot of a report by Emma O'Kelly of RTÉ and freedom of information
column3: FOI
column4: requests that were submitted in respect of this matter
column5: that there was very considerable lobbying by the Catholic bishops
column6: the Association of Trustees of Catholic Schools
column7: former heads of County Dublin vocational education committees
column8: VECs. These bodies were clearly unhappy with the initial circular
column9: a positive document which stated that people have the right to opt out of religious education and have alternative subject choices.It is not clear from the Minister's reply whether that still stands. Do people have the right to opt out and have alternative subject choices in line with what was stated in the first circular? I absolutely believe that they should have such a right. People should not be forced to have religious education or instruction imposed on them. To be honest
column10: the sort of distinction that is being drawn between religious education and religious instruction is a bit bogus. Can we get clarity on this matter?

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	277	Yes
column2: we can try if the Deputy will let the Minister answer.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	278	I will. By the way
column2: I thank the Minister for his words. I share the sentiments he expressed about the Business Committee. I wish him good luck with his new portfolio.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	279	I forced the Deputy to wish me good luck.

#RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	280	I had to reciprocate.

#JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	281	I will ensure that I get proper clarification. I will direct my officials to do that. I have some additional information that I hope will be helpful. As a former philosophy student at Maynooth University
column2: I agree with the idea that space should be provided within the curriculum for people to address many of the difficult questions we all face on a day-to-day basis. That does not mean instruction. There is no religious-specific instruction within the religious education syllabus. As part of its normal inspection processes
column3: the Department's inspectorate will inspect whether the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment's religious education subject is being delivered in schools in accordance with the requirements of the circular that was published recently. Schools have discretion in the context of religious education. They may choose not to offer the subject at all. If religious education is to be mandatory or optional in any particular class
column4: group or year
column5: it is to be treated the same as all other subjects
column6: such as history or geography
column7: for these purposes. It is subject to inspection. I reiterate that religious education is a separate subject. It does not involve instruction in any one faith or another. It probably provides an opportunity to broaden the discussion regarding well-being at a time when children and young people have different anxieties and pressures that teachers are dealing with. At this morning's meeting of the joint committee
column8: we discussed how to make progress in the area of well-being. I certainly think there is value in this approach.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	282	To be honest
column2: the Minister has not provided the clarity I am seeking. Do people still have the right to opt out of religious education in favour of alternative subject choices? The Minister's failure to give me a clear answer suggests they do not have that right in some instances. I was also a philosophy student. At my first philosophy lecture in UCD
column3: a priest who was a member of Opus Dei - there were many of them in the UCD philosophy department - said that before he and his colleagues started to teach us about all the great philosophers
column4: he wanted us to know that Karl Marx
column5: Nietzsche and a whole load of other secular radical philosophers were not philosophers. He said that St. Thomas Aquinas was a philosopher. That was the start of our philosophical education. It was informed by the Catholic religion through and through and that is how it followed. We cannot have that.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	283	It must not have worked on the Deputy.

#RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	284	It absolutely did not work on me. That kind of approach is not acceptable. The approach we are advocating needs to be absolutely clear. This subject should be changed from religious education to philosophy and should include other world views that have nothing to do with religion. We should look at religious views in the context of all views of the world
column2: but that is not what we are getting. People should have the right to opt out of religious education.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	285	I repeat that it is the prerogative of each school to decide whether to offer this subject. My information tells me that instruction from the perspective of any individual religion is not part of this. I am happy to continue the conversation on philosophy because I think young people need space to reflect. As a convent boy who was educated in a Loreto secondary school
column2: I value the philosophy and the caring and compassionate ethos that is espoused by the Loreto order. That is my perspective. It is not coming from the Department of Education and Skills.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	286	One can get that from Karl Marx as well
column2: by the way.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	287	I was more of a Descartes fan in philosophy. We have to be very clear about what happens when schools make decisions. My philosophy and vision for my new job is that schools should be empowered to make their own choices.

#CatherineMartin	unknown-#CatherineMartin-party	unknown-#CatherineMartin-dob	unknown-#CatherineMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	288	Ba mhaith liom gach rath a ghuí ar an Aire ina ról nua. I wish the Minister well in his new role and thank him for engaging so positively with the joint committee earlier on the important topic of mental health promotion in our schools. This question relates to the capitation grant
column2: which was increased by 5% in the recent budget. The primary and secondary school capitation grant is still well below the 2010 level. Does the Minister intend to restore the grant fully in line with the commitment in the 2016-19 action plan for education? If so
column3: what is the timeline for that?

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	289	The Deputy will be aware of the many pressing demands in education which my predecessor and his predecessors
column2: including Ruairí Quinn
column3: have had to consider in recent years. Important changes have been made. Provision for children with special educational needs has been resourced and reformed
column4: junior cycle reform has been rolled out
column5: school leadership has been strengthened
column6: primary class sizes have been reduced
column7: guidance teachers have been restored
column8: provision has been made for extra students at all levels and provision has been made for new skills needs in apprenticeships
column9: traineeships and higher education. I fully recognise the need to improve capitation funding for schools. I was pleased that my predecessor
column10: Deputy Bruton
column11: was able to provide for a 5% increase in capitation funding for primary and post-primary schools. This will apply from the start of the 2019-20 school year. I must be prudent in the context of ongoing budgetary pressures. As it is not possible to do everything I would like to do in the education sector in one year
column12: especially in the light of increasing enrolments
column13: I have to prioritise. To answer the Deputy's question in as black-and-white a manner as possible
column14: I intend to seek funding for further capitation increases in future budgets.

column1: #CatherineMartin	unknown-#CatherineMartin-party	unknown-#CatherineMartin-dob	unknown-#CatherineMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	290	I appreciate that the previous Minister
column2: Deputy Bruton
column3: had to consider which of the many issues he faced he should prioritise. Schools have been pleading for capitation increases for many years. The increase in the recent budget was something
column4: but it was very small. Capitation grant funding is still well below where it was in 2010. It is hardly surprising that the INTO has described it as a "pittance"
column5: given that it equates to just 4.6 cent per student per day. As the ASTI has stated
column6: the increase will merely keep up with growing student numbers. It is simply not adequate for the real costs of running schools in Ireland today. Principals are under huge financial stress as they seek to make the money stretch. School costs in my constituency of Dublin Rathdown can be higher
column7: but principals have the same amount of money per student to work with as principals in every other part of the country. Schools are buckling under this weight. We spoke at the joint committee about relieving the stress that is being experienced by teachers and principals. The stress in this area could be relieved by means of proper restoration of the capitation grant. According to the action plan
column8: this was supposed to begin in 2017 and was to happen over three years. However
column9: it now appears that the first sign of an increase will be in 2019. What is the clear timeline on which principals
column10: parents and teachers can rely?

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	291	I know from my travels around my constituency in recent years that the capitation grant always comes up when I speak with principals of primary and secondary schools. The grant is a lifeline for many schools as they seek to meet their running costs. There was a massive reduction of 11% in 2009. We have increased it by 5% this year. Annual funding would need to increase further by approximately €25.5 million if grants are to be restored to pre-2011 levels. I will not give the Deputy a false picture of how we can get there in a specific period. However
column2: I can give her a commitment that we will have conversations on this matter when we look at our 2019 programme. I have no doubt that it will be discussed at the joint committee. I want the committee to feed into the three-year strategic plan so that we can ascertain how to get there as quickly as possible.

column1: #CatherineMartin	unknown-#CatherineMartin-party	unknown-#CatherineMartin-dob	unknown-#CatherineMartin-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	292	I appreciate the Minister's commitment. Along with my colleagues on the joint committee
column2: I will hold him to it because actions speak louder than words. The committee held a specific summer school on school costs in September. The impacts of diminished capitation grants are twofold.First
column3: principals are continually stretched beyond the beyond in order to make the most of the money they receive. This is complicated by the minor works grant being announced later each year. It appears that there will be no grant for 2018 and that it will instead come in 2019. That is a major stress on schools when they are trying to work out where everything goes. Second
column4: the pressure placed on parents to cover the gap through voluntary contributions was emphasised at the summer school. We are burdening parents not just with the increasing costs of sending their children to school
column5: with uniforms
column6: books
column7: etc.
column8: but also with trying to keep the schools afloat. That is not acceptable. Parents receive an annual letter from schools seeking voluntary contributions
column9: but these are far from voluntary. I need to see action soon. What our principals need now are fewer of the circulars like those to which Deputy Boyd Barrett referred and more investment in schools.

column1: #SeanOFearghaillFF	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-party	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-dob	unknown-#SeanOFearghaillFF-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	293	Deputy Thomas Byrne wishes to ask a supplementary question on this matter.

#ThomasByrne	unknown-#ThomasByrne-party	unknown-#ThomasByrne-dob	unknown-#ThomasByrne-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	294	I was disappointed with the budget allocation for capitation. It was something that my party leader prioritised and numbered among the range of issues in the negotiations. While the Minister was not involved
column2: there seemed to be a major reaction against giving something significant in the capitation grant
column3: perhaps because Fianna Fáil was seeking it. That was a dreadful way to approach not only children's needs but also the commitment in the programme for Government to ensure an increase in the capitation grant
column4: in which respect nothing has been done. It was a major disappointment for schools that the grant was not increased. They will continue to struggle for money and come to the Minister seeking emergency works when proper works could have been done at the right time if the necessary money had been available.

column1: #JoeMcHugh	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-party	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-dob	unknown-#JoeMcHugh-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	295	This is an issue and it is one of a number of priorities I raised with my officials yesterday. I made the point that we have to find a pathway in the short-to-medium term to put extra revenue into capitation. I have committed to that. I look forward to working with the Deputies on establishing a consensus regarding how to reach to that point. Having met a number of officials from my Department - I have not met them all because there are 1
column2: 300 in total working hard in Athlone
column3: Tullamore and Dublin - I get a sense that they are heeding the importance of long-term planning for schools. Deputy Catherine Martin mentioned the minor works scheme. That money needs to be announced this side of Christmas
column4: as does the funding for the summer works programme. We need to consider giving schools more lead-in time. They face enough pressures and have a great deal on their plate. There are principals who are teaching
column5: performing administrative tasks and carrying heavy loads. The overall issue is something that I will be very conscious of in my role.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	296	There is a deafening silence from the Government regarding the rogue Saudi state's murderous activities in Yemen that have brought 13 million to 14 million people to the brink of starvation
column2: amid warnings of the worst famine in 100 years
column3: in a war in which tens of thousands have already been killed and millions of others displaced. Virtually the entire population of Yemen is now dependent on humanitarian assistance. Saudi Arabia
column4: with backing from the United States
column5: the UK and France
column6: is to a large extent responsible for this unfolding humanitarian catastrophe. With American-made weapons
column7: it killed 40 children in a school bus on a school trip in August. In June
column8: it hit a cholera treatment centre run by Doctors Without Borders when it was clearly marked as a medical facility. In April
column9: it killed 20 members of a family at a funeral in the north west. The atrocities go on. In the past week
column10: there was the barbaric killing of Jamal Khashoggi
column11: the journalist
column12: at Saudi Arabia's embassy in Turkey. What will we do about this? Why the silence? Are we going to speak out about the incredible hypocrisy of standing by while all of this is happening when our Government is doing beef deals with Saudi Arabia and the US
column13: the UK and France are selling the latter arms? After the Salisbury attack
column14: our Government moved rapidly to expel Russian diplomats. Where are the expulsions of Saudi Arabia's ambassador and diplomats?

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	297	The control of the story of Yemen and the spin surrounding it are scary. Our own State broadcaster
column2: RTÉ
column3: cannot mention the Houthis without saying "Iranian-backed Houthis" despite the fact that it has no evidence of this. I have not seen anyone else produce such evidence either. The Houthis robbed most of their ammunition and guns from former President Ali Abdullah Saleh's government forces. The current trouble in Yemen began with people protesting about neoliberal adjustments introduced under Saleh. He lost control
column4: but the US-Saudi coalition forced him out. In 2012
column5: his vice president
column6: Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi
column7: was installed as interim leader and continued the neoliberal agenda. It was all part of a process of plundering Yemen that has been going on for many years. However
column8: Hadi could not gain control either
column9: so he sat down with the opposition in Yemen and
column10: in September 2014
column11: signed the Peace and National Partnership Agreement with Ansar Allah
column12: the main opposition
column13: and the leaders of all the major political parties. Between them
column14: they agreed to have elections. That was not what the Saudis wanted
column15: however. It did not suit them. They started their airstrikes afterwards. Under the cover of UN Resolution 2216
column16: Saudi Arabia and the US self-authorised their use of violence in Yemen. The situation is horrific. We are at a stage where the Saudi-United Arab Emirates coalition
column17: backed by the US
column18: the UK
column19: France and Germany
column20: is bombing the people of Yemen into starvation. Only this week
column21: the UN stated that up to 13 million people were at risk of starvation. Did the Minister raise this matter at the Foreign Affairs Council earlier in the week and did he raise it while appealing for Irish membership of the UN Security Council?

column1: #SimonCoveney	unknown-#SimonCoveney-party	unknown-#SimonCoveney-dob	unknown-#SimonCoveney-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	298	I have been monitoring the state of affairs in Yemen with growing anxiety
column2: particularly in recent weeks as reports of the increased threat of famine have circulated. I am deeply concerned by the level of violence in Yemen and by reports of violations of human rights and international humanitarian law. Three years of war have had devastating consequences for civilians. Yemen is now the world's largest humanitarian crisis
column3: with more than 22 million people
column4: or three quarters of the population
column5: requiring some form of humanitarian assistance and approximately 2 million people internally displaced. The latest report from the UN's humanitarian co-ordinator in Yemen
column6: Ms Lise Grande
column7: sounds an alarm that between 12 million and 13 million Yemeni citizens will be at acute risk of famine in the coming months if the conflict continues. Ireland has provided almost €16.5 million in bilateral humanitarian assistance to Yemen since the conflict began in 2015. Of this
column8: €4 million was contributed in March to the UN Yemen humanitarian fund. Ireland pledges global funding to a number of organisations that are particularly active in Yemen
column9: including the World Food Programme
column10: UNICEF and the International Committee of the Red Cross. Ireland also contributes to EU support for Yemen. Since the beginning of the conflict in 2015
column11: the EU has allocated more than €438 million to the crisis. It supports therapeutic feeding centres for the treatment of malnourished children
column12: healthcare
column13: food aid programmes and emergency assistance to displaced populations. Humanitarian access is a critical issue so that aid can reach those who need it. There is a pattern of difficulties with this in Yemen. Commercial access is equally important
column14: since a population of over 20 million people cannot survive on aid alone indefinitely. This has been one of my consistent messages to all parties involved in the conflict.Officers from my Department consistently convey the Government’s strong concerns to the Saudi
column15: United Arab Emirates and Iranian Embassies in Dublin. I met the Saudi ambassador this afternoon and stressed the emphasis that Ireland puts on this issue as well as the issue raised by the previous Deputy. Both at UN level and in EU discussions on the issue
column16: Ireland has sought at all times to stress that military action will not be sufficient to bring a lasting solution to the conflicts between communities in Yemen. Military victory
column17: even if it is achievable
column18: will not address the root causes of the conflict. The pursuit of military victory also brings an unacceptable cost for the Yemeni people on a humanitarian level. We have seen time and again the tragic results of the errors and recklessness which are endemic to conflict situations. Negotiations must be reinvigorated
column19: and Ireland and the EU fully support the work of Martin Griffiths
column20: the UN Special Envoy for Yemen
column21: and his team. The Government is also vigilant for opportunities to make any progress we can in international fora
column22: including on ensuring accountability for crimes committed during the conflict. At the Human Rights Council in September 2017
column23: Ireland was part of a small core group of countries that drove forward the adoption by consensus of a resolution establishing a Group of Eminent Experts on Yemen. I personally worked closely with the Dutch Foreign Minister at the time
column24: Bert Koenders
column25: on this resolution. The group established is carrying out investigations into all alleged violations of human rights and international humanitarian law by all warring parties in Yemen. Last month
column26: Ireland worked to ensure that the mandate of this group was extended for a year
column27: to allow more time to complete its vital work. I assure the Deputies that Ireland will continue to take every appropriate opportunity to urge stronger international action
column28: and will press for a negotiated settlement to the conflict in Yemen.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	299	There are no angels among states and governments in the Middle East but the Saudi regime is a murderous
column2: brutal
column3: rogue one that is the enemy of democracy. It is willing to use the most savage methods
column4: including now bombing Yemen into a famine situation which will affect the entire population
column5: and to do so openly and blatantly. Also
column6: as we saw with the Khashoggi affair
column7: a journalist who wished to speak out and call for a free press and the right of people in the Middle East to criticise regimes like this
column8: is brutally murdered by people who have been clearly identified now as associates of Crown Prince bin Salman. What are we going to do about that? The Minister referred to talking to all parties involved
column9: but this is a rogue regime and the United States and the United Kingdom continue to arm these people to kill people in Yemen and murder a person in an embassy in Turkey. Can the Tánaiste explain to me the reason we expelled Russian diplomats after the attack in Salisbury and we are not expelling the Saudi ambassador and Saudi diplomats after what has been done in Yemen and with Jamal Khashoggi?

column1: #MickWallace	unknown-#MickWallace-party	unknown-#MickWallace-dob	unknown-#MickWallace-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	300	I am disappointed with the Tánaiste's answer
column2: and he did not answer my two questions either. Did he raise the plight of the people of Yemen and the threat of starvation this week at the Foreign Affairs Council or did he just talk about the journalist? I am amused that the journalist is getting such coverage and the ordinary people of Yemen are being starved to death. It has been established by an independent body that the majority of the bombing in Yemen has hit non-military targets. They are literally bombing food supplies now in order to starve the people. Whatever about what is going on in Yemen among the different parties in terms of who should be running the country
column3: the bombing has to stop. The Tánaiste spoke about humanitarian aid. Give us a break. The people who are giving humanitarian aid are the same people providing the bombs. Representatives of Médicines Sans Frontiéres were before the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade today. War is a self-sustaining industry. We have the Germans
column4: the French
column5: the British and the United States providing the bombs. The same people who are bombing hospitals are providing funding to rebuild them
column6: thereby creating work. It is a little like Halliburton making more money in Iraq than some of the bomb makers who dropped the bombs in the first place that caused the destruction. Providing humanitarian aid is not a solution. Stopping the bombing must be the start of a solution. Ireland should be fighting this at a European level.

column1: #SimonCoveney	unknown-#SimonCoveney-party	unknown-#SimonCoveney-dob	unknown-#SimonCoveney-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	301	We are. When the Deputy raises issues such as this
column2: and he is genuine when he raises them
column3: he is normally well-informed. Calling for the bombing to stop is one thing; actually making it happen is another. The way Ireland can be effective in doing that is to work through EU channels to try to do it. I am not quite sure what the Deputy is asking me to do. I have raised the Yemeni issue and the Yemen war on multiple occasions. There was not a long debate on it in this week's Foreign Affairs Council so I was not able to do it but that is not an indication of the fact that I have not raised this issue and spoken about it
column4: in particular in regard to the humanitarian impact of conflict and the need to bring that conflict to an end. That is why there is a UN Special Envoy for Yemen. The EU supports that special envoy to try to find a way forward on that. That is why I raised it only a couple of hours ago with the Saudi ambassador in my office
column5: along with the issue of Jamal Khashoggi.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	302	But there were no sanctions.
#SimonCoveney	unknown-#SimonCoveney-party	unknown-#SimonCoveney-dob	unknown-#SimonCoveney-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	303	With respect
column2: Deputy
column3: that is because we do not have the full facts yet. As usual
column4: the Deputy wants to be the first out to call for-----

column1: #SimonCoveney	unknown-#SimonCoveney-party	unknown-#SimonCoveney-dob	unknown-#SimonCoveney-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2018-10-18 00:00:00	Ceisteanna - Questions	316	I am glad to have the opportunity to respond to the Deputies. This week we learned of the tragic death of a man on the grounds of Galway City Hall on Monday
column2: 15 October. I join the Taoiseach and others in this House in extending my sympathies and condolences to the family of the man who died. Clearly
column3: this is a very difficult time for those involved
column4: and I ask that we respect the privacy of the family and do not speculate on the circumstances of the deceased or the cause of his death. As to the need for the Minister for Housing
column5: Planning and Local Government
column6: Deputy Eoghan Murphy
column7: to visit Galway city and to see the housing situation for himself
column8: I assure the Deputies that he is fully cognisant of the housing issues and pressures in Galway city. The Minister recently visited Galway and held discussions with senior officials in the council on homelessness and wider housing issues. The Government is increasing the funding to all local authorities to provide services to those experiencing homelessness. This year the estimated expenditure on homeless services for the west
column9: of which Galway City Council is one of four local authorities
column10: is €5.2 million. This will increase further in 2019. Supporting rough sleepers is a particular priority. Last month
column11: the Minister for Housing
column12: Planning and Local Government and the Minister for Health jointly launched the national implementation plan for Housing First. Many of those rough sleeping have requirements for significant health supports. As such
column13: Housing First is a collaboration between the Department of Housing
column14: Planning and Local Government
column15: the Department of Health
column16: the HSE and the local authorities. Housing First recognises that a stable home environment is critical to the success of all other interventions
column17: and by providing the necessary supports alongside rather than in advance of a home
column18: we can empower people to tackle the issues that resulted in them becoming homeless in the first place. The implementation plan will see this highly effective programme to reduce and end rough sleeping and long-term homelessness extended nationwide. The plan sets an overall target of more than 660 tenancies
column19: with individual targets for each local authority. It is one of the most significant responses by the State to date in dealing with long-term homelessness. Under the plan
column20: 30 Housing First tenancies will be created for Galway city over the next three years
column21: with a further 19 tenancies in Galway county. A tender process is under way in Galway to deliver these tenancies. Supports for families experiencing homelessness in Galway city are also being reinforced. Galway city’s first family hub is due to open in early 2019. Galway City Council has also identified a site for the roll-out of a modular hub development to be operational in the first half of 2019. It is expected that 15 families will be accommodated for up to six months at a time on this site
column22: if necessary. The principal advantages of these units are that they are quick to erect on site
column23: portable and redeployable elsewhere. A place finder service has been put in place
column24: with a dedicated officer funded by the Department
column25: to support households experiencing homelessness in identifying and securing a property in the private rented market. The long-term solution to homelessness is increasing the supply of homes
column26: as I am sure the Deputies will agree. A range of measures are being progressed in this regard under Rebuilding Ireland to accelerate all types of housing supply
column27: including social
column28: private and affordable. By 2021
column30: 000 new social houses will be provided and housing output generally will be progressively increased towards the target of producing 25
column31: 000 houses per year. Galway City Council has a target to deliver 145 new social homes in 2018 and about 1
column32: 100 between 2018 and 2021 through build
column33: acquisition and leasing initiatives. In addition
column35: a further 254 families or individuals will be housed through the HAP or the rental accommodation scheme. This will bring the total delivery of social housing supports in 2018 to approximately 400. Despite all of those numbers
column36: I am well aware of the pressures in Galway. Those pressures were there when I was the Minister for Housing
column37: Planning and Local Government and they persist. There are pressures in other cities too. What we are doing is ensuring that
column39: local authorities are supported. There should be enough emergency accommodation in every town and city in the country for individuals and families who find themselves homeless but
column41: we are committed to putting the resources in place to provide such accommodation.

column5: as well as being a university town and a town with a large institute of technology
column6: GMIT. There is no property available to rent. The HAP scheme is not the most lucrative market and there are other markets available to property owners. There are approximately 19 tourist accommodation providers in the city
column7: for example
column8: apart from Airbnb. There is obviously a strong market in the tourism sector. We have been told that 1
column9: 100 social houses will be built by 2021. There is one simple step that could be taken tomorrow that will speed up that process. It is the same step that the Government took when it created Irish Water. It provided the money to the utility and allowed it to get on with the job. I cannot understand why local authorities are not being given money at the beginning of the year and being told to do the job. They should not have to keep going back to the Department for approval time and again
column10: which means that it takes them an average of 59 weeks to get permission to build a house.

column4: Dublin

column2: the proposal was one of a number of measures developed as part of the Dublin City Centre Transport Study
column3: which was a joint initiative by the Council and the National Transport Authority. The issue of congestion is one which formed the backdrop to that study and forms the backdrop to city centre transport today also. The measures proposed by the transport study were designed to address the transport issues facing the core city centre area
column4: facilitate the implementation of the Council’s development plan and safeguard the future development of the city. In line with those objectives
column5: the study put forward a number of proposals around an improved public transport offering for the city. Since the study’s publication in 2015
column6: the NTA also published its statutory Transport Strategy for the Greater Dublin Area and we have this year witnessed the publication of the national development plan and now have visibility of the proposed funding allocations over the next ten years. A number of recently completed projects have already served to improve the capacity and quality of public transport in Dublin. Since 2015
column7: Luas cross city has opened
column8: heavy rail services have expanded through the re-opening of the Phoenix Park tunnel and ten-minute DART trains have been introduced.We have invested in improved cycle routes and expanded public bike-sharing schemes. We have also invested in new bus services and a new fleet and improved passenger experiences through the roll-out of real time passenger information and the continued development of the Leap card. These are positive developments. We know that we need to continue to increase our levels of investment in public transport and active travel measures
column9: which we plan to do under the national development plan. The Deputy will be well aware of the substantial investments planned to improve the bus network and infrastructure through the BusConnects programme to which she referred disparagingly. The NTA and Transport Infrastructure Ireland are continuing to plan for MetroLink with a view to construction commencing in 2021 and services being ready to start by 2027. The NTA is continuing to work with Iarnród Éireann on the expansion of the DART
column10: which will see the network electrified as far as Drogheda to the north
column11: Maynooth to the west and Hazelhatch to the south west. The issues underlying the development of the 2015 study remain and the NTA will continue to work with all stakeholders
column12: including the council
column13: to improve public and sustainable transport options in the city centre. The Deputy should note that the Government and the Minister set policy
column14: but we also allocate funds. Not to acknowledge the progress made in the expansion of the DART
column15: with ten-minute DART services
column16: the Luas cross-city service
column17: the proposals for BusConnects and the increases in public service obligation
column18: PSO
column19: funding is disingenuous. This is mainly a matter between Dublin City Council which made the application and An Bord Pleanála
column20: the planning authority
column21: which made the judgment.
